newsitem.title: USA: Leader Lott doubtful on U.S. Senate tax action.
newsitem.headline: Leader Lott doubtful on U.S. Senate tax action.

text.p: Senate Republican Leader Trent Lott voiced doubt Wednesday that the Senate would be able to act on a tax cut bill before it adjourns at the end of September.
Lott, R-Mississippi, told reporters he favored various tax cut proposals but "reality is I don't think we can get it done in September."
He said his target date for adjournment prior to the November 5 elections was Sept 27-28.
Lott said he was concerned that tax legislation would be loaded up with numerous provisions that would not help the economy.
He said he favored a number of tax-cut proposals, including some made by President Clinton, although he said Clinton's capital gains tax cut plan for homeowners was too narrow.
Lott said he still hoped the Senate could act on some form of a $0.043 a gallon cut in gasoline taxes, proposed by presidential candidate Bob Dole when he was majority leader.
Senate Finance Committee aides have said that any tax cut bill would open the door to a "Christmas tree" of provisions sought by many senators.
